com:
https://chat.openai.com/chat

Record your screen and save it as a webm
Remember to pip install the necessary packages, and it also requires you install ffmpeg.

import numpy as np
import cv2
from mss import mss
from moviepy.editor import *
import datetime
import subprocess

# Get the current time
current_time = datetime.datetime.now()
time_str = current_time.strftime('%Y-%m-%d-%H-%M-%S')

output_file_name = "screen_capture-" + time_str
res_width = 960
res_height = 780
monitor = {"top": 200, "left": 580, "width": res_width, "height": res_height}

def screen_capture():
    print("Recording to " + output_file_name + '.mp4')
    print("Press Q to stop recording...")
    # Create a screen capture object using the mss library
    sct = mss()

    # Define the codec and create VideoWriter object
    fourcc = cv2.VideoWriter_fourcc(*'mp4v')
    out = cv2.VideoWriter(output_file_name + '.mp4', fourcc, 20.0, (res_width, res_height))

    # Capture the screen and save it to the file
    while True:
        # Get raw pixels from the screen
        sct_img = sct.grab(monitor)

        # Convert the pixels to a numpy array
        frame = np.array(sct_img)
        img = np.flip(frame[:, :, :3], 2) # dumb shit t o fix colors
        img = cv2.cvtColor(img, cv2.COLOR_BGRA2RGB)

        # Show the frame
        cv2.imshow("Screen Capture", img)

        # Write the frame to the video file
        out.write(img)

        # Press Q on keyboard to stop
        c = cv2.waitKey(1)
        if c == ord('q'):
            break

    # Release the VideoWriter object
    out.release()
    cv2.destroyAllWindows()

    # Run the command-line argument
    result = subprocess.run(['ffmpeg', '-i', output_file_name + '.mp4', '-c:v', 'vp8', '-an', '-b:v', "5M", output_file_name +'.webm'])

    # Print the return code
    print(result.returncode)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    screen_capture()

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>90271544
>Whats the difference between a mechanical mechanism and an algorithm
A mechanical mechanism is a physical device that uses moving parts to perform a specific function or task. An algorithm, on the other hand, is a set of instructions or steps that are followed in a specific order to solve a problem or accomplish a task.

In other words, a mechanical mechanism is a tangible, physical thing, while an algorithm is a logical, abstract concept. Mechanical mechanisms are typically used to perform mechanical tasks, such as moving objects or converting one form of energy into another, while algorithms are used to solve problems or accomplish tasks that can be represented in a logical or mathematical way, such as sorting a list of numbers or finding the shortest path between two points.

In summary, the main difference between a mechanical mechanism and an algorithm is that a mechanical mechanism is a physical device, while an algorithm is a logical set of instructions.

com:
As someone who has used both Rust and C, I have to say that I think Rust is a better programming language than C for a number of reasons.

First of all, Rust is a safer and more secure language than C. Because Rust has a strong type system and uses borrowing and ownership concepts, it can prevent many common security vulnerabilities such as buffer overflows and null pointer exceptions. This makes Rust a great choice for building secure systems.

Another reason why I think Rust is better than C is that it has better performance. Rust is a compiled language, which means that it can be as fast as C, but it also has higher-level abstractions and a more modern language design. This makes it easier to write efficient code without sacrificing readability.

Additionally, Rust has a great community and ecosystem. The Rust community is known for being friendly and welcoming, and the language has a growing number of libraries and tools that make it easy to build a wide range of applications.

Overall, I think Rust is a superior language to C because it is safer, more performant, and has a great community and ecosystem.

com:
This is the best browser. It's not just competently made - a fork of the best browser on the market, but it's also not made for profit or malicious intent. It has no callbacks to Google out of the box, and is made by good devs who don't have to wrestle with Mozilla every update or so (Google is far more lax with updates resetting settings and breaking things generally). Optionally, you can get full access to Google's web store which contains more extensions than any other browser, and you don't have to justify using a hipster browser when other people see you use your PC.

You're getting a top notch big-tech browser the way it should've been. A win-win really.
Most people use Chrome, so it's also easier to make the transition to this browser without it feeling like a cheap knock-off (aka Firefox in 2022).

You cannot refute this without slippery slope fallacies like "W-well if you use Ungoogled, Google will win the browser market!". First off, they already have. And Mozilla are aiding them by striking deals with them and selling your info to them, and that's just the best case scenario. Second, not using superior technology because of a slippery slope is retarded. It's literally luddite thinking in the same vein as "If we don't get the vaccine, our economy will collapse". Thirdly, why would you want to help promote shitty software like Firefox in the first place? Even Brave is better, but Brave likes to change personalization settings to shill crypto, so it's really Brendan's browser and not yours; unlike Ungoogled.

People do a lot of irrational things, but not using Ungoogled Chromium is one I just don't think I'll ever understand.

>>90254701
read it if you want to get enterprisey jobs. also to understand the programmer who wrote the ObserverBuilderAbstractFactoryFactory.java.
It's mostly out of date these days, given most of the patterns are supplanted by dependency inj/IoC and languages becoming multiparadigm. Most languages have "design patterns" built in these days, such as events and iterators. anyway a boring historical text, I would recommend head first design patterns over it.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>90254701
>i think that you could've come up with equal solutions without adhering to respective pattern spec
the point is that the implementation is recognizable and predictable

>i think if you keep most language features in your head most of the time, you would not need to remember patterns
some design patterns are covered by language features in some languages, but most aren't
and it's not objectively better to have every pattern as a language feature; the more features, the more complicated the language itself
the language being simple is a fair tradeoff for not having some design pattern as a feature

>i think it might be harmful to prefer some specific snippets over language features
design patterns are not snippets
and again, not all design patterns are covered by language features

>because you'll unlikely have just 1 factory or 1 observer per project and end with a bunch of more specific ones because you can't or shouldn't abstract all the way
that's on you not to go overboard with patterns
the whole point is that certain patterns are for specific problems: if the problem isn't what the pattern is for, don't apply the pattern
and abstracting specific logic is an issue beyond/orthogonal to design patterns, i.e. you can apply a design pattern only if there is already a clear abstraction (the pattern won't magically fix the abstraction for you)

Users of all levels are welcome.
Share Windows tools, utilities, tips & tricks.

FAQ:
>How do I activate Windows?
https://github.com/massgravel/Microsoft-Activation-Scripts
HWID mimics upgrade activation to generate a permanent legitimate license.

>>Which version should I install?
>Home/Pro
Comes with bloatware apps (games, music, news, weather, etc)
>Education/Workstation/Enterprise
Comes with basic system apps.
>LTSC / IoT LTSC
LTSC = 5 years support, VL/KMS only
IoT LTSC = 10 years support, HWID only
Comes with Win32 system apps, no MS Store, no feature updates, security updates only.
If you need MS Store, run this in cmd: wsreset -i

>Do I even need IoT LTSC?
W10 Home/Pro/Edu/WS/Ent editions end support in 10/2025, LTSC in 2027, IoT LTSC lasts until 2032.

>How do I activate Office?
https://github.com/abbodi1406/KMS_VL_ALL_AIO/releases
Installs a KMS server emulator, not ideal as KMS trips AV sometimes and deactivates. Alternatively, use MSOffice through your browser since it's free. As a last resort, you can try OnlyOffice/LibreOffice/WPS/Polaris and set it to save as MSOffice file formats.

>Where can I get Windows/Office ISOs?
https://massgrave.dev/genuine-installation-media.html

Check it via the account panel in the settings menu to see if it is.
Also if you don't have internet on it right now, I could list out some manual tweaks you can make for more privacy.
>Turn off every toggle in the privacy panel in the Windows Permissions section from general to activity feed
>Turn off location if its on
>Search for the Services admin panel and disable and stop the Connected User Experiences and Telemetry & Device Management Wireless Application Protocol (WAP) Push Message Routing Service services
>Search for the Task Scheduler admin panel and disable everything inside the Application Experience and Customer Experience Improvement Program tasks, which is inside Microsoft\Windows
>Create the AllowTelemetry DWORD in HKLM\Software\Polices\Microsoft\Windows\DataCollection via the registry editor and leave it set to 0
>Disable Cloud Protection and Automatic Sample Submission in Defender's settings
Just a small amount of things you can manually do to get a more private system.

Including the one that censpored images of Winnie the Pooh online, as the beloved bear - as depicted by illustrator E. H. Shepard - was felt to resemble, and mock, China's president-for-probably-life Xi Jinping. The Register therefore suggests it will be a very, very, brave Chinese developer that creates a photorealistic ursine chatbot or avatar.

The regulations also spell out how the creators of deepfakes -- who are termed "deep synthesis service providers" -- must take care that their AI/ML models and algorithms are accurate and regularly revised, and ensure the security of data they collect. The rules also include a requirement for registration of users -- including their real names. Because allowing an unknown person to mess with deepfakes would not do. The rules are pitched as ensuring that synthesis tech avoids the downsides and delivers benefits to China. Or, as Beijing puts it (albeit in translation), deepfakes must "Promote the healthy development of internet information services and maintain a good ecology of cyberspace." The regulations come into force on January 2023.
